The second part, from Good men and women, a good and virtuous friend is like a loving mother, is the teaching and encouragement. It means teaching
the method of serving friends.
The text has four sections, all using analogies to illustrate.
The first is teaching to contemplate the superior virtues of friends. In it, first praising the superior virtues, and then concluding the encouragement below always be like this.
The second, from Furthermore, you should serve, is teaching to give rise to the mind and practice of serving friends. There are twenty-one sentences, the text is clear.
The third, from Furthermore, you should in your own body, is the mutual comparison of the body and friends. The text has ten sentences, each sentence has four things, which can be known.
The fourth, from Good men and women, you should give rise to such a mind, is the conclusion and encouragement of the benefits.
In it, there are two parts:
First, the correct encouragement; second, from Why is it so? citing the benefits to explain and accomplish.
In it, there are also two parts:
First, it correctly explains the benefits of the Dharma friend, and then below Furthermore it praises the friend as being able to benefit, and therefore one should serve them.

The third, below Good sons, to summarize, concludes both the admonitions and encouragement of the two approaches, meaning that specific explanations are difficult to exhaust, so it concludes the extensive from the brief.
Within it there are also two:
First, it concludes the many by borrowing a number, and then below I will further briefly explain it generally includes and concludes the many.
Since it is all-encompassing, how can it only be a hundred thousand? It is clear that what was said before about ten inexpressibles is meant to show that it is inexhaustible.
The sixth, below At that time Sudhana, is reverently parting with his virtues.
Below this, the third major text is about one person, Maitreya, clarifying the aspect of perfecting causes by embracing virtues.
Since previously merging conditions and entering reality is definitely capable of becoming a Buddha, it clarifies the meaning of perfecting causes as a regent in one life.
The text only has five sections, as the position of a regent is extremely evident, lacking humility and pushing forward.
The first, according to the teaching, is heading towards seeking, within it there are two:
First, it summarizes the previous thoughts and points to the future, and second, from recollecting it specifically generates superior thoughts to regret the past and cultivate the future.
Within this, there are four:
First, contemplating past faults to practice countermeasures.
Second, from further contemplating this body it contemplates the present suffering and encourages future goodness.
All practitioners should carefully examine this and emulate it.
Third, from when contemplating in this way it clarifies the benefits of contemplation and thought, and benefits the superior contemplation.
Fourth, from all of this it concludes the benefits and their corresponding aspects.
Second, from the youth Sudhana it shows respect and asks questions.
Within this, there are two:
First, showing respect, and second, asking questions.
Within the former, there are also two:
First, showing respect to the dependent, and second, showing respect to the principal, each with expressions of respect.
Within the former, there are two:
First, expressing respect while in concentration, and second, praising after emerging from concentration.
Within the former, there are three:
First, concluding the previous and pointing to the following, second, specifically manifesting the function of concentration, and third, concluding with the benefits achieved.
Now, first,

Positional mindfulness is the determination, contemplation is the added practice of concentration, and faith and vow are the causes of concentration. Entering omnipresence distinguishes the name and characteristics of concentration.
2. Universally manifesting and below specifically reveals the function of concentration, which is the simultaneous operation of concentration and wisdom.
In this, there are two parts:
1. Clarifying the wondrous function of concentration that is wisdom.
In this, first the body clouds are extended throughout the Dharma realm, and then below equal to empty space it accords with the true source of the nature of dharmas.
2. Moreover, one definitely knows and below clarifies the profound contemplation that accords with the Dharma realm.
In this, there are three parts:

First, understanding dharmas arise from conditions; next, below free from annihilation the wisdom accords with the absence of nature; third, below knowing all dharmas are like seeds producing sprouts it unifies and returns to the middle way.
These three unobstructed [gates] are the three contemplations in one mind.
Now, first.
Repaying good and evil, therefore it is said karma arises.
The fruit itself arises from its own seeds, therefore it is said arises from causes.
Cultivating oneself to become a buddha, faith is the source of the Way.
It causes the manifestation of the nirmÄá¹‡akÄya, and respect arises.
In the second, within the non-nature, free from inverted views refers to the four inverted views.
The four inverted views are: regarding the impermanent as permanent, this is called an inverted view. Seeing the true principle, there is no such inversion.
If one regards the impermanent as permanent, this is also not seeing things as they really are, because it is a state of destruction.
Self-mastery view means that the god ÄªÅ›vara can create myriad things, therefore.
One knows that it is due to one's own karma, and thus it is not due to others.
Free from the views of self and other means that if one single-mindedly grasps self and other, then it goes against dependent origination.
Extreme views means firmly grasping the beginning and end of saá¹ƒsÄra, etc.
Free from existence and non-existence means that what arises from non-existence is called birth, and what returns from existence to non-existence is called cessation.
The essence is neither born nor ceases, so how can there be existence or non-existence?ğŸ”½Knowing emptiness and non-arising, one eliminates phenomena based on principle.
Knowing non-self-mastery, one eliminates phenomena based on conditions.
Knowing that one is born through the power of vows, one eliminates phenomena based on causes.
Third, returning to the Middle Way: each phrase is free from the above faults, but now it is explained in general.
As seeds produce sprouts, they arise from conditions such as water and soil, so they are not nonexistent, like the first section.
Since arising from conditions has no nature, they are not existent, like the second section.
Not existent and not nonexistent is precisely the Middle Way. In this way, one can contemplate and understand the avoidance of annihilationism and eternalism, etc.
The horizontal analogy of seeds and sprouts for myriad dharmas is like the vertical analogy of imprints produced by a seal.
The Nirvana Sutra says, This aggregate ceases, and the other aggregate continues to arise.
It is like a wax seal imprinting mud, where the seal is destroyed and the imprint is formed.
The following phrases apply to both the horizontal and vertical.
Understanding that the world is manifested by the mind is also the contemplation of mind-only. Taking the mind as a condition, manifestation without nature, is the contemplation of the Middle Way.
The rest can be understood.
Third, The youth Sudhana concludes with the benefits attained.
Second, rising from the ground praises after emerging from concentration.
There are three parts:
First, respectfully circumambulating with the body; next, with this thought he said and below, respectfully contemplating with the mind; later, in the verses, respectfully praising with speech.
In the second, taking the virtues of the abider and praising the abode of the tower, the first line is fully revealed, therefore.
This word great tower runs through all the lines.
In it, it is divided into ten:

First, it shows the superiority based on the realm, second, from this is entering all profound it shows the subtlety based on virtue, third, from therefore, for one eon it shows the mastery based on function, fourth, from this is in front of all sentient beings it shows the superiority based on practice, fifth, from this is able to abide in the difficult to know Dharma it shows the profundity based on contemplation, sixth, from this abides in great compassion it shows the superiority based on counteracting, seventh, from this although abiding in the four dhyanas it shows the mastery based on calming and contemplation, eighth, from this although in all karmic afflictions it shows the superiority based on the practice of benefiting others, ninth, from this although practicing the nine successive concentrations it shows the mastery based on the practice of protecting the lesser vehicle, tenth, from this great multi-storied pavilion it concludes the abode of virtue.
Among the previous nine, excluding the first two and the fifth, the rest are all based on the dual practice of skillful means and reality, phenomena and principle.
In the third praise with words, there are fifty-five verses, divided into two:
The first thirty-four seven-character verses praise the place based on its merits, while the last twenty-one five-character verses point to the place and clarify its merits.
Within the former, there are two:
The first two are general praises, one about stages of practice and one about renowned virtues;
The remaining verses specifically discuss merits and practices, within which there are four:

The first has seven verses about the superiority of self-beneficial practices, the second has ten verses praising the superiority of benefiting others, the third has eight verses praising the superiority of merits and virtues, and the fourth has seven verses praising the superiority of skillful means.
Within the latter five-character verses pointing to the place and clarifying its merits, although it speaks of relying, the intention is to praise the true.
Within this, there are six:

The first two are lower transformations, the next two are higher contemplations, the third has five verses clarifying the mastery of samÄdhi, the fourth has seven verses clarifying the vast and profound wisdom, the fifth has one verse revealing its equality,
And the sixth has four verses concluding the merits and virtues, expressing respect, seeking compassion, and requesting empowerment.
The second, at that time, below is the vision of the true body, within which there are two:
The first is seeing, the second is respect.
Seeing has two parts:
First, with a yearning mind he wishes to see; later, after he saw, he properly beholds the compassionate honored one.

The statement coming from another place means that subsuming conversion is based on the capacity of beings, and returning is to revert to the original. It also shows that Maitreya responds to thoughts and arrives without being attached to a location.
The second, Subsequently, Sudhana saw... shows the manner of paying respect.
Within this there are five parts:

First, with body and mind he pays homage; second, after At that time Maitreya... praises his virtues and makes predictions; third, after At that time Maitreya... again expresses the manner of paying respect; fourth, after At that time Maitreya... again praises and again makes predictions; fifth, after At that time Sudhana... rejoices in the encounter and thinks of the kindness.
The second has two parts:
First, prose.
Indicating means causing the assembly to see together, as a model for practice.
Later, the verses properly praise, with 113 verses, divided into three parts:
First, one verse points out and generally praises the assembly; the last verse briefly indicates the later friend; the verses in between specifically praise the superior virtues.
There are three parts to this:
First, twenty-two verses directly praising Sudhana, also in three parts:
First nine verses praising his virtues and welcoming him;
Next two verses clarifying the causes of his coming, because externally he relies on good friends and internally possesses virtuous practices;
The last eleven verses clarify the purpose of his coming.
Second, from You all should observe... there are twenty-six verses exhorting the assembly to praise.
There are five parts to this:
First four verses are general praise;
Next four verses praise his compassion that is wisdom;

Next seven verses praise his wisdom that is compassion. Artha means objects of knowledge. The Treatise on Entering the Great Vehicle says, The stage of artha refers to the tenth stage. This is based on completely eliminating the ten kinds of obstructions to knowledge.
Next six verses are general praise of various virtues;
The last five verses praise the wonderful fruition that will be accomplished.
Third, from Your practice... there is praise directed at Sudhana.
There are five parts to this:
The first twenty-six verses praise his future fruition virtues, the first two are general, the rest are specific;
Second, the seven verses from You praise his future and present virtues;
Third, the eight verses from All faculties praise his virtue of encountering friends;
Fourth, there are five verses praising his virtue of quickly accomplishing stages and practices;
Fifth, there are seventeen verses generally clarifying all virtues and concluding with praise to make one rejoice.
The third is reiterating respectful conduct, which has three parts:
First, discerning the cause of respect, because of hearing praise of virtues;
Next, from Sudhana heard the body and mind are sorrowful and respectful;
Later, from with Manjushri flowers are offered to show sincerity.
As for the power of Manjushri's mind, it shows that it is due to faith and wisdom.
The virtues of the flower are established, and the practice of the necklace is accomplished.
As for filling the hands, it is because faith and wisdom are complete.
Scattering to Maitreya is because of gathering and accomplishing the cause, and because of accomplishing the future fruition.

The fourth is the second praise and second prediction, and the fifth is rejoicing in the encounter and thinking of the kindness. The text is all understandable. Below this is the seventy-eighth chapter.
The second, At that time, the youth Sudhana joined his palms and below is the inquiry, which has two parts:
First, he declares his resolve, and after But I do not yet know he correctly inquires about the essential Dharma.
Within this there are three parts:
First, he states what he is inquiring about.
Next, Great Sage, all TathÄgatas and below praises Maitreya's virtue of being able to answer, and uses this virtue to also serve as the basis for the inquiry, first generally and then specifically.
The specific has fifty phrases, all the virtues of the perfect cause and full fruition.
Third, Great Sage Bodhisattva and below concludes the inquiry and requests explanation, and also reveals the meaning of the inquiry.
The third, At that time, Bodhisattva Maitreya and below praises and bestows the Dharma.
Within this there are two parts:
First, praise, then bestowing the Dharma. The first of these has two parts:
First, for the sake of the great assembly he praises Sudhana, which is praising the person;
Later, for Sudhana's praise of the bodhi mind, it is precisely the praise of the Dharma.
In the former, there are also two parts:
First, pointing out the person to the assembly; later, from All good people, this son of a good family... he correctly praises his virtues.
In this, there are four parts:

First, clarifying the diligent seeking of friends; second, clarifying the vastness of what he rides; third, clarifying the completeness of virtues without deficiency; fourth, clarifying the swift realization surpassing the provisional.
In the first, there are two parts:
First, generally clarifying diligence.

Later, from all good people... he specifically shows the aspect of diligence, meaning that diligence in one time is still not to be praised, but since the beginning until now there has been no slackening in thought, therefore it is to be praised.
As for the one hundred and ten good and wise advisors, there are many ancient explanations.
One says:
The principle should be complete, but the text is missing.
Zhizhe says:
The friends before and after total fifty-four positions, dividing out BhadrapÄla and Sudhana makes two, then fifty-five people, each having their own and superior progress, thus one hundred and ten.
If one relies on this explanation, then it contradicts the word already here.
Since it says that after one hundred and ten, one then reaches Maitreya, Maitreya and the other three are clearly not the number one hundred and ten.
Some say:
It is only ten less in number, actually one hundred and eight people.
That is to say, before this, excluding PÅ«rá¹‡a, there are only fifty-one people, each possessing host and companion, making one hundred and two.
PÅ«rá¹‡a points out ViÅ›vakarman, although not a host friend, he is a companion friend, making one hundred and three.

Adding the place of King Aá¹£á¹­amaka, the empty god SthiraÅ›raddhÄ, the place of Queen MÄyÄ, the goddess of the Dharma of the lotus flower, the god of wonderful flowers and light, and the rÄká¹£asa of the Dharma hall who guards well with good eyes, together with the previous total of one hundred and eight.
Because they ask and answer each other using the characteristics of the empty heavens and so forth, they are counted as friends.
They are not the main friends who are named and pointed out, so they are not the main friends but are called companion friends.
If that is so, then it contradicts the words the remaining cities below.
It is explained below that before reaching the boy and girl, it has already been one hundred and ten.
Now it is said remaining because it is after the place of MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«.
If this is the one hundred and eighth, adding Maitreya is still only the one hundred and ninth, and adding MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« is only the one hundred and tenth. How can there be any remaining?

If it is harmonized, all three explanations can be used. Taking the previous and adding the bodhisattva who awakens in the immovable place and the celestial messenger of the TathÄgata, it becomes one hundred and ten. Then the meaning of remaining is also established.
Because those two sages also teach Sudhana, they can be companion friends.
The words the remaining are merely the translator's intention.
The Jin edition does not have the character already, which then takes both before and after, without obstructing the meaning.
However, below it again says one hundred and ten cities and passing one hundred and ten yojanas. All that say one hundred and ten have something they represent.
That is to say, excluding the Buddha stage, taking the realization and entry into the ten grounds and equal enlightenment as one hundred and ten, because one contains ten.
It also shows that each stage has ten interpenetrations. Even if there are three sagely stages, they only have ten.

If equal enlightenment is combined with the superior progress of the ten grounds, then the ten faiths are opened into one. Therefore, whether advancing or retreating, the arrangement and the perfect interfusion both accord with the words one hundred and ten. Why must one be fixed on the sequence of before and after?
The second, from Good men, this son of a wealthy family is extremely difficult to have, clarifies the vastness of what is ridden.
Within this there are three:
First, generally praising the rarity.
Second, from Such a person, it specifically clarifies the difficulty of encountering, within which there are two:
First, it raises the question, and then below why is it so? it inquires and explains.
The meaning of the explanation is as follows:
Because the rescue is profound and vast, it opens up the previous general statement of saving and protecting sentient beings.
Within this, there are two parts:
First, it clarifies the general protection of all; second, below for those who are swept away by the four streams, it specifically clarifies based on types.
Gobbling is the appearance of rapid currents.
As for the city of the realms, it refers to the eighteen realms. Each of the faculties, objects, and consciousnesses has separate liberation.

As for the realms and stages, it refers to the four elements such as earth. The empty aggregation of the six sense bases is ignorant and without a person. If it is not guided by the light of wisdom, it will certainly be robbed by the thieves of the dust.
Third, all good people, this son of a wealthy family always uses concludes what he has done.
Third, all good people, if there are sentient beings clarifies the complete virtues without deficiency.
There are thirteen sentences, one of which is already rare, let alone two or three, up to the complete possession, therefore it says more and more difficult to have.
Moreover, the latter is more difficult than the former, thus it says in succession.
Fourth, all of you below clarifies the rapid realization surpassing the provisional, because it relies on the true teaching to practice.
It means that in the very body of an ordinary person, in one lifetime, one also realizes the life of practice and understanding.
A thousand-year-old bird is not as good as a phoenix born in the morning. The stages of birth and position of Samantabhadra mutually interpenetrate and include each other.
Those who rely on true practice are all able to do so. Why not strive for it?
The text has ten sentences:
The first two sentences generally clarify the practices of all the stages, the third enters the ten abodes, the fourth and fifth enter the ten practices, and the sixth enters theè¿´å‘.
Moreover, the above four sentences are also the practices of the ten grounds, and the above four meanings contain both general and specific meanings.
The following four sentences are common to all stages and positions.
Second, at that time Maitreya below praises the bodhicitta for Samantabhadra.
The text is divided into two parts:
First, concluding the previous and generating the next, then addressing Samantabhadra below praises.
There are four parts within this:
First, it praises the arousing of the mind;
Second, below You have obtained good benefits, it praises the vessel for arousing the mind and the benefits it brings;
Third, below Why is it so? it extensively cites the virtues of the mind of enlightenment to explain it;
Fourth, below Good man, the mind of enlightenment accomplishes such, it concludes the explanation and relates it to what belongs to it.
The first two are understandable.
In the third, it first raises the question, Why is it so?
The meaning of the explanation is:
Because the mind of enlightenment is endowed with virtues.
There are 221 sentences, all of which generally refer to the three kinds of arousing the mind and suddenly possessing the virtues of all stages.
It is roughly divided into two parts:

The first 118 sentences clarify that the mind of enlightenment pervades all stages, and the second 103 sentences below Obtaining the fearless medicine clarify that the mind of enlightenment suddenly possesses the virtues of all stages.

Moreover, the former part mainly clarifies the accomplishment of faith and the resolve and practice of the bodhicitta, while the latter part mainly clarifies the resolve of the bodhicitta in the stage of realization, thus the text often says attains.

Moreover, the former part clarifies the supreme merit of the bodhicitta, which is equal to the fruition of Buddhahood, while the latter part compares the merit of the bodhicitta's mastery to be vast and immeasurable.
Now, in the first part, it is divided into two:
First, it clarifies individually; later, it concludes in general.

The text is both horizontal and vertical. Horizontally, each resolve of the bodhicitta is endowed with the merit of the various phrases. Vertically, it specifically matches the resolve of the bodhicitta with the various stages, because from the seed nature of the bodhisattva up to the ultimate, it does not go beyond the three kinds of resolve of the bodhicitta.
Guangtong matches it with the twelve abodes:
The first three phrases are the abode of seed nature, thus it says like seeds, like fields and land, all of which are the meaning of giving birth to seeds.
The second, the six phrases below like clear water, clarify the benefits within the abode of superior understanding and practice.
The third, the sixteen phrases below clear eyes, are the abode of greatly joyful increase, because they are all the meaning within the first ground.
The four like the great ocean and below seven sentences are the superior abiding of precepts.
The five taming the wise elephant and below ten sentences are the superior mind abiding.
The six good medicine and below ten sentences are the superior wisdom abiding associated with the factors of enlightenment. The so-called vidyÄdhara means universal removal.
The seven wish-fulfilling jewel and below ten sentences are the superior abiding associated with the various truths.
The eight sharp knife and below ten sentences clarify the superior abiding associated with the arising and cessation of dependent origination.
The nine bedding and below ten sentences clarify the abiding with effort in the signless.
The ten life root and below ten sentences clarify the abiding without effort in the signless.
The eleven good lineage and below ten sentences clarify the abiding of unobstructed understanding.
As for life and practice, the Sanskrit version says it is like a magnet, because it does not attract the liberation fruits of the hearers.
The twelve pure lapis lazuli and below sixteen sentences clarify the supreme bodhisattva abiding.
The Sanskrit says Indra's net, taking the net to mean afflictions and asuras.
The wind called BÄrhaspatya means a swift and fierce wind.
The meanings in the text all correspond to those stages, but for fear of being too verbose, I will not elaborate.
From the seeds to the end of the afflictive habits, the meaning of verticality is clear.
However, the cutting of habits and so forth, pushing the merit back to the original mind, then the horizontal endowment of various virtues is clear in principle.
Second, Good sons, and below is the summary, which is the accomplishment of merit due to the initial stage.
The initial mind is endowed with various virtues, let alone the perfect interfusion of the beginning and end.
Third, Good sons, it is like, and below, in one hundred and three sentences, it clarifies the merit of the self-mastery of the bodhi mind.
In the text, each has a metaphor and a combination, because the listeners see deeply and far, therefore, the metaphors cited are mostly not of the ordinary realm.
It also shows that it is not shared with the bodhi mind.
Although it is both horizontal and vertical, it is divided into five sections, just as the previous section is divided into five.
The first seven sentences summarize the virtues of the ten abodes, because the mind of enlightenment is by nature free from evil thoughts and so forth.
The second, the root of non-arising, and below, ten metaphors summarize the virtues of the ten practices.
The third, Åšakra's wearing of the maá¹‡i, and below, nine sentences summarize the virtues of the ten dedications.
The fourth, there is a jewel named pure light, and below, sixty metaphors summarize the virtues of the ten grounds, which are divided into ten:
The first four summarize the virtues of the first ground;
The second, like the sovereign king, and below, three metaphors summarize the virtues of the second ground, because the merit of upholding precepts, ascetic practices, and so forth is pure;

The third, the method of well-taming dragons, and below, four metaphors summarize the virtues of the third ground, because one enters various meditative absorptions and is free from the heat of delusions and so forth.
The fourth, Mount Sumeru, and below, four metaphors summarize the virtues of the fourth ground, because one is the same as the flame of omniscience and attains the undefiled.
The fifth, the coconut tree, and below, four metaphors summarize the virtues of the fifth ground, because one benefits others without being tainted by worldly affairs.

9. The ten similes below taking an elixir of longevity summarize the virtues of the ninth ground, because they prolong life, benefit life, etc.

10. The six similes below like a medicine empowered by a mantra summarize the virtues of the tenth ground, because they deeply eliminate the habits of delusion and accomplish all the qualities of a Buddha.
5. The seventeen similes below the vajra is not an inferior vessel summarize the merits of the stage of equal enlightenment, because with the vajra-wisdom one finally attains enlightenment.
The Sanskrit terms are all in the Sounds and Meanings.
The fourth, from Good sons, the mind of enlightenment below, concludes and explains what it belongs to, meaning that the many virtues above explain the words obtaining good benefits.
The second, from Good sons, as you have asked below, is the correct bestowal of the Dharma realm.
In this, there are four parts:

First, bestowing the essence of the Dharma; second, revealing the name of the Dharma; third, exhausting the fundamental source of the adornments; fourth, investigating the nature and characteristics of the correct body.
In the first, there are four:
First, the expedient of embracing and entering; second, the empowerment to see and enter; third, seeing the realm of what is seen; fourth, the completion of the matter and rising from concentration.
In the first, first quoting the question and encouraging the realization below enters the seventy-ninth scroll;
Later, from At that time, Sudhana below, seeking the expedient of realization.
The second, from At that time, Maitreya below, empowering to see and enter.
First, empowering based on conditions, causing them to forget words and understand the meaning based on the Dharma, then the Buddha's Dharma door opens, thus saying going forward and so on.
This is opening the door of wisdom and principle, showing and causing them to realize and enter.
Later, Sudhana was delighted and below, in terms of his own realization of the cause, he awakened to the Buddha's knowledge and vision and entered the Dharma realm.
From delusion to awakening, with the distinction of the approach of added effort and the principle of the gate,
once realized, they accord with each other, and subject and object are both forgotten. Delusion itself is true, and there is no more place to enter, so it is said to be closed again.
Third, seeing the pavilion below clarifies the seen realm of realization.
Within this there are two parts:
First, specifically clarifying what is seen, and second, generally revealing the characteristics of seeing.
The first part has six sections:

First, seeing the dependent reward, second, seeing the true reward, third, seeing the bodhisattvas who are companions, fourth, seeing the buddhas, fifth, seeing the main pavilion within the pavilion, and sixth, generally seeing the functioning of the adornments. However, these six are all within compassion and wisdom.
Now, first seeing, then benefiting.
In the former, there are three parts:
First, directly seeing one level of adornment, with a heading, list, and conclusion.
The same as empty space is because it accords with the nature of phenomena.
Next, from and also saw within it is the reliance on the intermediate state of existence.
One sees many in the intermediate state, which is the subtle gateway and also the host and guest gateway.
Later, from the youth Sudhana is seeing many in one place, which is the gateway of mutual containment.
Second, from at that time is the explanation of the benefits gained.
Second, from as soon as he bowed his head is seeing the true body, which has two parts:
First, generally indicating, from so-called below is specifically revealing.
Within this there are five:
First, seeing the time of first arousing the mind;
Second, from sometimes seeing the initial attainment of compassion below is seeing the time of practicing and attaining the Dharma;

Third, from sometimes seeing Maitreya as a wheel-turning king below is the time of subsuming and nurturing according to type; fourth, from sometimes seeing as a world-protecting god below is seeing the Dharma being expounded in the assembly, within this, first clarifying the differences in the assemblies, later from sometimes seeing praise of the first ground below revealing the Dharma being expounded;
Fifth, from sometimes seeing Maitreya in a hundred thousand below is generally seeing the functioning.
The third, from Or they see the bodhisattvas below, clarifies seeing the bodhisattvas' bodies and clouds expounding the Dharma, which is the retinue of immeasurable numbers mentioned above.
The fourth, from Or again, in the middle, they see the tathÄgatas below, clarifies seeing the merits of the buddhas' embracing and transforming.
The fifth, from And again, in that below, seeing the main pavilion in the pavilion, specifically clarifies Maitreya's future attainment in one lifetime.
In it, first seeing, then at that time below gaining benefits, can be known.
The sixth, from Again, they hear all below, seeing and hearing the functioning of the adornments, in it there are ten sections:
First, hearing the nets and so forth expounding the Dharma, in it there are three:
First, hearing nearby, next Again, they hear in such and such a place below hearing from afar, later Sudhana below gaining benefits;
Second, seeing the functioning of the jeweled mirror;
Third, seeing the jeweled pillar emitting light;
Fourth, seeing the jeweled image's deportment;
Fifth, seeing the production of necklaces and so forth;
Sixth, the lotus flower appearing again;
the reflection of the seven treasures appears;
the eight trees manifest half the body. Dousha luo means frost and ice;
